Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is creating a replicable, prototype community-based model for engaging middle and high school students in challenge-based programs such as robotics competitions (Botball and iARoC), engineering challenges (Kid Wind), and research events (Sea Perch). The project is serving 110 teachers and 750 students representing 7 school districts and 75 schools. Partners include organizations that broadly represent the science educational institutions of the San Diego area. There is a cadre of volunteer STEM professionals who are mentoring teachers and students. The goals include increasing motivation for 6th-12th grade students; preparation of teachers to use challenge-based learning; establishment of a virtual network for collaboration; and development of a sustainable model for all of San Diego County. The project is using culturally relevant strategies and social learning networks as a communication tool, with an emphasis on disadvantaged students in San Diego County, especially the large population of Hispanics. Students are presenting their work in several local STEM-related community events.

The research findings are contributing to the current literature regarding engagement in challenge-based programs, especially in comparing how out of school experiences compare with formal school settings in the areas of career choice, post secondary choice, and success in STEM disciplines. The research is using a quasi-experimental design with both quantitative and qualitative data. The products include online learning modules and a model for a bilingual STEM Career Fair Night. An attractive feature of the project that could be transformative is a model organizational structure in which a relatively small organization, San Diego Science Alliance, provides coordination, communication, and inspiration that marshal the STEM education efforts of a large number of bigger institutions across a major urban area. This structure is leveraging and maximizing the local resources efficiently and effectively. The model is being made available to be replicated in other large cities with similar resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to create a community-based model for engaging middle and high school students in hands-on, STEM competitions to enhance their interest in STEM careers. The project tested the impact of three engineer challenges, evaluating the impact of these programs on the quality of teaching about STEM and on student engagement. The program built a network of collaborators within K-12 systems, higher education, STEM industries, and the community to create a local culture focused on increasing STEM literacy for 6-12 grade students and their teachers. The grant focused on three key activities:  Botball -- a program based upon competition between robots, SeaPerch -- a program based upon robot "fish" in pools, and KidWind -- a program based upon designing and building effective wind turbines.

Based upon the analysis of teacher surveys, free-form responses by teachers and students, registration and retention of students for the programs, and successful completion of student projects, each of these STEM programs successfully achieved the following goals of this grant: 

(1)   Increased student motivation to learn STEM content and related skills by participating in challenge-based programs with the support of a teacher who has gained experience in hands-on and conceptual aspects of the project.

(2)   Preparing teachers to use challenge-based learning to engage their students in STEM activities.

(3)   Building a network of educators, community stakeholders, and industry representatives to enhance STEM education in the San Diego Region.

The activities also enhanced the awareness and interest in STEM careers for students, teachers, parents, and the community.

The fourth goal of the grant was to develop a sustainable model for scale-up across San Diego County school districts. This goal is more challenging because of the difficulty of acquiring resources for equipment and supplies and support for teachers on a continuing basis without the availability of grant funds. Although building the activities into the curriculum could reduce this problem, this approach will require seamlessly integrating these activities into Next Generation Science Standards and/or Common Core Curriculum to offset the time teachers have available to commit to extracurricular activities.

During the course of this project, the San Diego Science Alliance is now being facilitated by the Ruben H. Fleet Science Center. This has brought together the majority community organizations focused on STEM education together with the regional school districts, generating a sustained STEM educational network, and the approaches and results of this study have been broadly integrated into the K-12 STEM education efforts in the San Diego region.
